content.description:
Up the smooth patina slab with just enough holds to start and more the higher you get. Fun.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Left side of the northeast face and just right of

Hanging Fire

.

content.description:
Grab the overhead lip of the boulder and make an awkward mantle to get established at the base of a tall slab which is followed to the top. The top-out it high but fairly easy.

There are some holds below the lip which could be used as a direct start at about V5 or so.

* This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Left side of the north face and left of

Bongo Man

.

content.description:
Up the nice grey slab with a a bit of technical footwork at the start then easier moves to the top.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Between

Bongo Man

and

Footprints

on the north face.

content.description:
Grab an overhead jug and make an easy mantle up and over the top. This could be a good problem to work on mantling technique.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location: South face and right of a thorny Acacia tree.

content.description:
SDS at a flat edge and work up and out the steep prow on edges and slopers to a mantle finish.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location: Right side of the east face at an arete.

content.description:
Climbs straight up the center of the nice grey slab with positive edges that appear when you need them the most.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.

Footprints

climbs a clean slab just left of an arete on nice grey rock with positive edges. This is also the downclimb for the boulder.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location: Right side of the north face.

content.description:
This easier version of

Flatface

tackles steep thin edges up and left to a prominent rail which gives access to the lip where an easy mantle tops it off.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.protection: pad, spotter (to keep you off a rock at the base)
content.location: Left side of the southwest face.

content.description: Crank sharp, thin edges up and right on a smooth and slightly overhung face on this technical crimpfest.

Make a difficult highstep/mantle onto the slab where it's undercut and then work up a shallow left-facing corner system to the top. Starting from

Give Thanx

and traversing left into the corner makes this a fun V-easy problem.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Left side of the north face and just right of

Struggling Man

.
